history.content:
Data 100 goes over some probability that is covered in 126. If you take 126 then you probably don't need to study any Data 100 probability because it would be the same but easier.

------------------------------------------------

No clue what the student above is saying, that's cap. EECS 126 is the hardest undergrad probability course on campus and covers a lot of content.

------------------------------------------------

Data 100 covers the probability that is merely more advanced than Math 55 or CS 70. But EECS 126 covers Markov Chain, Random Processes. Material wise, I feel Math 55 < Prob 140 < EECS 126 < Prob 140 + Stat 150.

children.subject: Also I think that 126 isn't easy by any means, but its difficulty gets exaggerated by students
<md>Thanks Ishaan!  That was very helpful. Can you please also comment on @13153 after reading all the comments in that post as to which 2 course combination might be an okay workload?</md>

Hmm for some reason my reply never got published, so I'll just give a tl;dr 

workload wise 126 ~ 127 (maybe slightly >) and 127 > 188. So workload wise 170 + 188 is easiest in that regard. That being said, neither class is particularly important for 189; in that regard, 126 and 127 are far more important. However, 170 is essential in terms of CS theory and 188 is essential if you're interested in AI and robotics, so viewing them only from the lens of their 189 relevance would be shortsighted. Hope that helps, if you have more specific questions then drop them below and I'll try getting back to them

@Ishaan - everyone keeps saying not to take 170+126 together. I have read your comments above. In your opinion, do students who have taken Data 100 before have a slightly better edge if they take 170+126 together in a semester? Thanks.

Well I'll say that whether you should take 126 and 170 together depends on your previous workload. I'd be a little weary of recommending it to the average student (although they could probably manage), but there are also students here at Berkeley who'd breeze through both classes if those were the only techs they were taking that semester. To answer your question, I believe Data 100 wouldn't offer much of an edge for 170 and 126 if you've already taken 70, since 70 focuses more on the probability theory you'd encounter in 126 than 100 anyway.

Also I'm hardly the end all and be all of course advice: if people who you trust and know you have given you advice, it's definitely worth considering, and arguably more valuable than a stranger's insight on the internet; I have only my own perspective to offer, and I hope it's helpful to the people here, but I also don't know your workloads and previous experience so my advice has to be a bit general by definition

I'm going to answer here because the student answer box is already pretty crowded. As you already noted, there's little to no overlap between 126 and 127. Data 100 covers a variety of topics, including but not limited to probability and random variables (which you cover in far greater depth in 126), and gradient descent and convexity (which you cover in far greater depth in 127). If possible I'd suggest taking Data 100 first, but either way it'll help motivate the applications of the aforementioned concepts and also covers other parts of the data science life cycle that don't show up in 126 or 127 much/at all

history.content: Hello, if I take these 3 courses together, will there be any overlap/concurrency between 126/Data 100 or 127/Data 100 material? (I know there's no overlap for 126 and 127, but don't know if there is any for Data 100)
history.subject: Overlap in Data 100, EECS 126 and 127?
